noteParagraph.text: Processes involving only a single technical art, e.g. drying, coating, for which provision exists elsewhere are classified in the relevant class for that art.

titlePart.text: PROCESSES OR MEANS, e.g. BATTERIES, FOR THE DIRECT CONVERSION OF CHEMICAL INTO ELECTRICAL ENERGY
titlePart.entryReference: electrochemical processes or apparatus in general
semiconductor or other solid state devices for converting light or heat into electrical energy , e.g. , ,

noteParagraph.text: This sub-class deals with galvanic primary or secondary cells or batteries, and fuel cells or batteries.

titlePart.text: Constructional details, or processes of manufacture, of the non-active parts

titlePart.entryReference: manufacture of accumulator cases from vulcanised rubber

titlePart.text: Arrangements for introducing electric connectors into or through cases

titlePart.entryReference: structural combination of accumulators with charging apparatus

titlePart.text: Vent plugs or other mechanical arrangements for facilitating escape of gases
Fixed connections, i.e. not intended for disconnection
Intercell connections through partitions, e.g. in a battery case
Methods or arrangements for affording protection against corrosion
with provision for preventing undesired use or discharge
Arrangements for filling, topping-up or emptying cases with or of liquid, e.g. for filling with electrolytes, for washing-out

noteParagraph.text: When classifying electrodes of hybrid cells, the individual half-cells of the hybrid cell are considered separately, e.g. an electrode in the primary half of a primary/fuel type hybrid cell is considered to be a primary-cell electrode covered by .

titlePart.text: Electrodes composed of, or comprising, active material
of pressed electrodes with central core, i.e. dollies
of consumable metal or alloy electrodes
titlePart.entryReference: use of alloy compositions as active materials

titlePart.text: Drying or preserving electrodes after forming
Precipitating active material on the carrier
Selection of substances as active materials, active masses, active liquids
Alloys based on magnesium or aluminium
of "Grey lead", i.e. powders containing lead and lead oxide
of inorganic compounds other than oxides or hydroxides
Selection of inactive substances as ingredients for active masses, e.g. binders, fillers
for lead-acid accumulators, e.g. frame plates
Containers for holding the active material, e.g. tubes, capsules
Shapes other than plane or cylindrical, e.g. helical
Multi-step processes for manufacturing carriers for lead-acid accumulators
titlePart.entryReference: single-step processes, see the relevant sub-classes, e.g. ,

titlePart.text: Inert electrodes with catalytic activity, e.g. for fuel cells
Non-porous diffusion electrodes, e.g. palladium membranes, ion exchange membranes

noteParagraph.text: Primary cells are electrochemical generators in which the cell energy is present in chemical form and is not regenerated.

titlePart.text: Dry cells, i.e. cells wherein the electrolyte is rendered non-fluid
Cells without oxidising active material, e.g. Volta cells
activated through external addition of electrolyte or of electrolyte components
containing electrolyte and made operational by physical means, e.g. thermal cells
Grouping of primary cells into batteries
Methodes or arrangements for servicing or maintenance, e.g. maintaining operating temperature
Reclaiming serviceable parts of waste cells or batteries

noteParagraph.text: Fuel cells are electrochemical generators wherein the reactants are supplied from outside.

titlePart.text: Auxiliary arrangements or processes, e.g. for control of pressure, for circulation of fluids
Combination of fuel cell with means for production of reactants or for treatment of residues
titlePart.entryReference: production of reactants per se, see Sections B or C

titlePart.text: operating at high temperature, e.g. with stabilised ZrO2 electrolyte
Biochemical fuel cells, i.e. cells in which micro-organisms function as catalysts
Indirect fuel cells, e.g. redox cells
Fuel cells in which the fuel is based on materials comprising carbon or oxygen or hydrogen and other elements
Fuel cells in which the fuel is based on materials comprising only elements other than carbon, oxygen, or hydrogen
Grouping of fuel cells into batteries, e.g. modules

noteParagraph.text: Secondary cells are accumulators receiving and supplying electrical energy by means of reversible electrochemical reactions.

titlePart.text: Assembling a group of electrodes or separators
Suspending or supporting electrodes or groups of electrodes in the case
Semi-lead accumulators, i.e. accumulators in which only one electrode contains lead
Accumulators not provided for in groups
Methods or arrangements for servicing or maintenance of secondary cells or secondary half-cells
Accumulators structurally combined with charging apparatus
Accumulators combined with arrangements for measuring, testing, or indicating condition, e.g. level or density of the electrolyte
titlePart.entryReference: indicating or measuring level of liquid in general

titlePart.text: Heating or cooling or regulating temperature
Removing gases inside the secondary cell, e.g. by absorption
titlePart.entryReference: vent plugs or other mechanical arrangements for facilitating escape of gases

titlePart.text: Reclaiming serviceable parts of waste accumulators

noteParagraph.text: Hybrid cells are electrochemical generators having two different types of half-cells, the half-cell being an electrode-electrolyte combination of either a primary, a secondary, or a fuel cell.

titlePart.text: composed of a half-cell of the fuel-cell type and of a half-cell of the primary-cell type
titlePart.entryReference: methods or arrangements for servicing or maintenance

titlePart.text: with one metallic and one gaseous electrode
composed of a half-cell of a fuel-cell type and a half-cell of the secondary-cell type
titlePart.entryReference: methods or arrangements for servicing or maintenance, e.g. for charging,

titlePart.text: Electrochemical current or voltage generators not provided for in groups
Structural combinations of different types of electrochemical generators
